t: Job 39
“Do*pn you know when the mountain goats give birth? Do*ld you observe the calving of the does?
Can*ln you number the months that they fulfill, and*ld do you know the time when they give birth,
when*ln they crouch, bring forth their offspring, and*ld are delivered of their young?
Their*ln young ones become strong; they grow up in the open; they*ld go out and do not return to them.
“Who*pn has let the wild donkey go free? Who*ld has loosed the bonds of the swift donkey,
to*ln whom I have given the arid plain for his home and*ld the salt land for his dwelling place?
He*ln scorns the tumult of the city; he*ld hears not the shouts of the driver.
He*ln ranges the mountains as his pasture, and*ld he searches after every green thing.
“Is*pn the wild ox willing to serve you? Will*ld he spend the night at your manger?
Can*ln you bind him in the furrow with ropes, or*ld will he harrow the valleys after you?
Will*ln you depend on him because his strength is great, and*ld will you leave to him your labor?
Do*ln you have faith in him that he will return your grain and*ld gather it to your threshing floor?
“The*pn wings of the ostrich wave proudly, but*ld are they the pinions and plumage of love?
For*ln she leaves her eggs to the earth and*ld lets them be warmed on the ground,
forgetting*ln that a foot may crush them and*ld that the wild beast may trample them.
She*ln deals cruelly with her young, as if they were not hers; though*ld her labor be in vain, yet she has no fear,
because*ln God has made her forget wisdom and*ld given her no share in understanding.
When*ln she rouses herself to flee, she*ld laughs at the horse and his rider.
“Do*pn you give the horse his might? Do*ld you clothe his neck with a mane?
Do*ln you make him leap like the locust? His*ld majestic snorting is terrifying.
He*ln paws in the valley and exults in his strength; he*ld goes out to meet the weapons.
He*ln laughs at fear and is not dismayed; he*ld does not turn back from the sword.
Upon*ln him rattle the quiver, the*ld flashing spear, and the javelin.
With*ln fierceness and rage he swallows the ground; he*ld cannot stand still at the sound of the trumpet.
When*ln the trumpet sounds, he says ‘Aha!’ He*ld smells the battle from afar, the*ld thunder of the captains, and the shouting.
“Is*pn it by your understanding that the hawk soars and*ld spreads his wings toward the south?
Is*ln it at your command that the eagle mounts up and*ld makes his nest on high?
On*ln the rock he dwells and makes his home, on*ld the rocky crag and stronghold.
From*ln there he spies out the prey; his*ld eyes behold it from far away.
His*ln young ones suck up blood, and*ld where the slain are, there is he.”
